page.title: 07WALTHAMS CROSS PART 2
page.content: They first lived in a tied cottage in Little Bardfield where he worked as a cowman. When their present cottage became vacant they moved in and rented it for 6 shillings a week, after which they bought it. Today's cars have not spoilt Walthams Cross but the narrow lanes have been made wider by cars wearing away grass verges. In winter Mrs. Turner gets snowed in and is unable to get out unless someone clears the road. There was no mains supply of water to the houses until 197O. Before this, water had to be collected from a pump a little way down the road. When it came to bath time buckets of water were fetched from the pump and put in a copper to heat. The water was poured into a long tin bath.Electricity was brought into the houses in 1951, just in time for Good Friday.
